description: I‚Äôm still here! I took an unplanned (and therefore unannounced) break from writing the blog, which was intended to be for a week, but expanded to a month and then two months‚Ä¶ WHOOPS. I confess I needed some time off from ye olde Frugalwoods after consistently posting for 9.5 years. That‚Äôs the longest I‚Äôve ever done any one job and I realized during this impromptu hiatus that I‚Äìgasp‚ÄìMISSED writing and MISSED all of you. Sometimes one must have some absence in order for one to realize what one misses. So, I‚Äôm checking in to let you know that I haven‚Äôt died or abandoned Frugalwoods, but that I am trying to discern how often I‚Äôll write going forward. The days of thrice weekly posts are definitively over, but on the other extreme, I don‚Äôt particularly want to take full months off again either. Thank you for your patience as I‚Äìonce again‚Äìfigure out what I want to do with my life. text: I‚Äôm still here! I took an unplanned (and therefore unannounced) break from writing the blog, which was intended to be for a week, but expanded to a month and then two months‚Ä¶ WHOOPS. I confess I needed some time off from ye olde Frugalwoods after consistently posting for 9.5 years. That‚Äôs the longest I‚Äôve ever done any one job and I realized during this impromptu hiatus that I‚Äìgasp‚ÄìMISSED writing and MISSED all of you. Sometimes one must have some absence in order for one to realize what one misses. So, I‚Äôm checking in to let you know that I haven‚Äôt died or abandoned Frugalwoods, but that I am trying to discern how often I‚Äôll write going forward. The days of thrice weekly posts are definitively over, but on the other extreme, I don‚Äôt particularly want to take full months off again either. Thank you for your patience as I‚Äìonce again‚Äìfigure out what I want to do with my life. I like writing and I like helping people with their money and I‚Äôm very thankful that I get to do just that. My vision going forward is to post a new Reader Case Study each month. The Reader Case Studies are the clearest distillation of what my work is evolving into: more helping other people with their money; less talking about moi-self. As longtime readers know, my writing on Frugalwoods began essentially as a money diary. A way for me to understand my own feelings about my money and how I wanted to create a different sort of life, one divorced from the rampant consumerism and hectic oneupmanship that dominates a large share of media in America. I‚Äôm humbled by how many folks have followed along these 9+ years and in awe of the deeply inspiring conversations, friendships and self-exploration this work has prompted for me. The other reason for my intended new focus on Reader Case Studies is the indisputable fact that‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm Tired Of Writing About Myself What I learned during this unplanned sabbatical is that, frankly, I‚Äôm tired of writing about myself. I‚Äôve spilled a lot of digital ink delving into my own finances, my financial psyche, and my approach to everything from making oatmeal to index fund investing. And it‚Äôs been fun! And rewarding! But as my kids get older, I‚Äôm less comfortable mining my life for content and less comfortable sharing the nuances of their lives. I also think I‚Äôve probably said just about everything I have to say‚Äìif not here on blog, then in my book. That being said, I want to continue our Frugalwoods community and continue serving as a resource for people at every stage of the financial journey. I envision that happening in a few ways going forward: Through a monthly Reader Case Study here on the blog, where we‚Äôll read through a reader‚Äôs real live finances and offer compassionate, productive feedback and advice. I also have a new search tool for the Reader Case Studies (of which there are 104) that enables you to search for specific Case Studies based on age range, income level, retirement plan, marital status, profession, location and more! I hope this will help folks find Case Studies that reflect their own financial situations and questions. Through the archives of this blog. There are 737 published posts on Frugalwoods in addition to my book, Meet the Frugalwoods. If you‚Äôre curious about my thoughts on any given topic, check out the new categories on the blog homepage. I did my best to re-organize old posts into consolidated categories to help with searching. Hopefully this is more easily navigable than my previous 8,000 different categories :). Through my one-on-one financial consultations and financial plans. If you‚Äôd like my help with your money, you can read more about what I offer and hire me here. I‚Äôll help you understand your entire financial situation, set clear goals, and provide practical solutions for managing your money. Through being interviewed on podcasts and the radio. I enjoy being on other people‚Äôs podcasts and, if you‚Äôre a podcast listener, you can keep up with the shows I‚Äôm on via this page. Through my free Uber Frugal Month Challenge (UFM). As most of you already know, you can take the Uber Frugal Month on your own at any old time. As you may also know, we take the UFM together every single January. This January will be our 7th annual UFM Group Challenge. Sign-up in the box below to join me! Does This Mean You‚Äôll Never Write About Your Life Ever Again? Nope! I‚Äôve learned to ‚Äúnever say never‚Äù since I often practice the art of changing my mind. I very well might come across a new challenge or discovery about myself in the future that‚Äôll warrant new posts (or another book) or‚Ä¶ who knows! But at present, I‚Äôm settled and content on my peaceful rural homestead with my husband of 15 years and our two daughters, now ages 5 and 8. I‚Äôm in a phase of deep gratitude for what we‚Äôve built and, in many ways, I have less to write about versus when we were in the striving-for-this-goal phase. We‚Äôre contentedly boring at this point, with no major news or financial revelations to share. Life‚Äôs good and I‚Äôm grateful. But, as all my fellow writers know, boring and happy often doesn‚Äôt translate into interesting content for readers. Life is long and unpredictable, so I may yet surprise myself and return to full-time blogging. Or not. Time will tell! But, I wanted you all to be aware of where I‚Äôm at in this journey so that you can continue to walk alongside me‚Äìif you want to‚Äìin this new iteration of Frugalwoods. It‚Äôs Time To Sign-Up for the January 2024 UFM Group Challenge! The UFM is a tradition I want to continue since it outlines the process my husband and I followed to kick-start our own frugal journey. It‚Äôs also the roadmap we used to reach financial independence. I also want to continue the UFM because I‚Äôve heard from thousands of folks that the Challenge changed their financial lives for the better. If you haven‚Äôt taken the UFM before, check out my FAQs: Q: What‚Äôs the UFM? Not to be confused with Underwear Fang Monkeys or Universal Folk-dancing Moths, the Uber Frugal Month Challenge (UFM) is my FREE, 31-day, holistic, emailed-based money re-vamp program. You can sign-up to take it at any time, but we take the UFM as a group every January. From January 1-31, I‚Äôll send you an email a day with specific steps on how to improve your finances. There‚Äôll be motivational mantras thrown in, but the primary purpose of the UFM is to give you detailed, straightforward, easy-to-follow financial action items. Woohoo! A lot of people (me included!) take the UFM every single year as a refresher course to help get back on track or to confirm that they‚Äôre still in great financial shape. Other people come to it as money beginners and end the month with new confidence about their finances. Still others are at expert level and take the course as a way to connect with the broader Frugalwoods community and offer encouragement and advice to newer community members. It‚Äôs fun (I mean, at the very least, it‚Äôs not painful), it‚Äôs free (totally free), and it‚Äôs written in plain English (no financial jargon allowed). The Uber Frugal Month isn‚Äôt just about saving money. It‚Äôs a holistic re-evaluation and re-structuring of our human relationship with one of the most polarizing, stress-inducing, divorce-causing, fear-mongering things: our money. Money does not have to be any of those things. Money can be a beast you tame, understand, and make work for you‚Äìnot against you. You can either master your money or it can master you. Join me and take charge. A few years ago I launched a private Facebook group for UFM participants to share ideas, discuss challenges and be in community together, which means your next question very well might be‚Ä¶ Q: How do I join the private Uber Frugal Month Facebook group? You‚Äôll receive a link to join after you sign-up for the UFM. If you‚Äôre already in this private Facebook group‚Äìwhich thousands of you are‚Äìdon‚Äôt worry, you don‚Äôt need to do anything. Just keep being awesome and supportive in the group! Q: Do I need to use Facebook (or other social media) in order to participate? Nope! The Challenge is conducted entirely via email and here on Frugalwoods. The UFM Facebook Group is an optional bonus. No need to sign-up for Facebook in order to participate in the UFM. All you have to do is sign-up with your email address in the box below. Q: If I‚Äôve already taken the UFM, can I take it again? Absolutely! I had my tech guy (AKA Mr. Frugalwoods) set up the email thing-y such that you can sign-up to re-take the Challenge with the same email address you used to take the Challenge previously. You do, however, need to sign-up again in order to join us starting January 1st. Real Live People Love The UFM!!! Thank you for the motivation!‚Äù -SK ‚ÄúI wanted to reply almost every single morning with solid reaffirmation of your frugal tenets. It‚Äôs great to see such a comprehensive guide through the frugal mindset. It reinforced that I‚Äôm on the right path, but discipline is required to keep in check. I think anyone who hasn‚Äôt adopted it might not understand the very real happiness you report. They should understand that you aren‚Äôt uniquely suited to this, your advice is extremely practical!I‚Äôll be here next year as a self check-up. Thank you so much!‚Äù -Adam ‚ÄúThank you so much for your daily emails and encouragement. It helped me to stay focused, to learn, and to implement new ideas and ways of thinking.‚Äù -Donna ‚ÄúIt was a delight to read all the emails from you. It made clear sense to not spend more on the things I would of spent my money on, but it was freeing to not do that‚Ä¶.I‚Äôve been on a frugal journey already, but to read your emails was such a delight to see all the suggestions that you gave. I‚Äôve kept some to go back and read them again. It gave me purpose to keep right on going‚Äù -Arthur ‚ÄúWhat was clear from the start was how many times I had to say no. It felt like every weekend there were just so many ways to spend money, but nothing was really needed. Saying no to frivolous expenditures was shocking at first, but half-way through the month it became my mission. Now I see that what I would have spent money on was just things, not needed things, just places to go, time to waste, etc. I saved some money, but that money will snowball if I continue next month, which I will! Thank you for this guided lesson, I learned so much‚Äù -Mary ‚ÄúThis UFM was surprisingly easy! It‚Äôs also my‚Ä¶third or fourth time trying it?- and none of those went well. I started out strong but fizzled out, falling back into old spending habits. This is the first time I‚Äôve done an UFM as a working parent (my son is almost 2), so I think the extreme lack of leisure time was helpful üôÇ But I also have a better understanding of¬†why¬†I am interested in frugality and the many ways it benefits me, my family, and the future we want.¬†This month has been a good reset. It hasn‚Äôt felt restrictive, it‚Äôs felt¬†empowering.‚Äù -Meredith Chickens: unconcerned about winter ‚ÄúI am very grateful for your writing and insights, especially this month‚Äôs frugality mindset series. Being frugal is my default setting, but it is still good to reset and give some neglected areas a little attention.‚Äù -Vanessa ‚ÄúThis month was enlightening for me. It was mainly because of the wonderful emails. The very thing I objected to on the challenge, I found to be great! I do have a long way to go on that front but I‚Äôm excited for the challenge. I feel this is a lifestyle to work toward & that is why I thank you. I absolutely love the Facebook community you have created also. Makes me feel warm & fuzzy!‚Äù -Jamie ‚ÄúMy month was great! I didn‚Äôt miss much and was able to use my savings to snowball extra money towards my daughter‚Äôs student loans. Win-win! Thank you for your inspiration!‚Äù -Christie ‚ÄúThis frugal challenge has been great for my wallet, my health and with my time management.
